Name: Throwback Blend
Review: A blend in which you can taste the influence of both the Colombia and the Kenya elements, the former chocolate-toned, the latter, sweetly tart. Combined, they generate a resonant, layered intricacy.

Name: Costa Coast Blend
Review: An inviting blend of two organic coffees, a Costa Rica and a natural-processed Ethiopia, which together create a spicy-floral-toned and fruit-driven cup.

Name: Canoe Blend
Review: A deep, energetic coffee that juxtaposes bright sweetness and rich earthiness with a dark chocolate throughline.

Name: Dead Reckoning
Review: A floral-toned blend with particularly engaging acidity, sweetly tart and lively structure, and an intriguing suggestion of fresh spearmint.

Name: Miami Winter
Review: A deeply attractive blend that evokes the tropics, with notes of ginger blossom and pineapple leading the aromatic charge.

Name: Wilderness Blend
Review: An elegant citrusy and chocolate-toned cup, pleasingly complicated by notes of stone fruit and rich aromatic wood.

Name: Naturals With Attitude
Review: All fruit, all the time. But not a hint of ferment, despite the blend’s four dried-in-the-fruit, natural-processed components.

Name: Guatemala Retiro Natural Process
Review: A dry-processed coffee in the crisp, elegant style, lightly cocoa-toned, subtly complex, long-finishing.
Coffee Origin: San Martin Jilotepeque, Chimaltenango Department, central Guatemala

Name: Gaitania Colombia
Review: Big-bodied, roundly powerful coffee expression, equally nuanced with cedar, dry chocolate and herb hints. Fair trade and organic.

Name: Rwanda Remera Kabeza
Review: An unusually pure Rwanda, impressive particularly in its fresh, juicy structure and bright composure.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe
Review: A resonant, chocolate-toned Yirgacheffe cup, deeply sweet with floral and aromatic wood undertones.

Name: Honduras David Mancia
Review: A pleasing stone fruit and cocoa-driven Honduras cup, bright and lively.

Name: Kenya Gatugi AB
Review: Elegant and complex: an expressive Kenya coffee with sweet-savory depth and engaging top notes of bergamot, butterscotch and red currant.

Name: Bufcafe Rwanda Espresso
Review: An unapologetically savory-sweet coffee, especially attractive in milk, where both basic taste tendencies are enhanced by notes of tamarind and citrus zest.

Name: Bufcafe Rwanda
Review: A superior Rwanda cup, classically sweet-savory with an appealing high-toned crispness.

Name: Gedeb Ethiopia
Review: A big, juicy wet-processed Ethiopia cup laden with rich floral and fruit tones throughout, all enveloped in dark chocolate.
Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia

Name: Civet Yirgacheffe Sisota
Review: An impressively rich sweet-savory cup with a throughline of fennel-like herb notes. Interesting both for its unusual cup and its unusual processing variation.

Name: Civet Ethiopia Papilio Sidamo
Review: A Sidamo coffee processed by the dry or natural method and treated with a cultured essence of kopi luwak that together net richly ripe fruit notes, cocoa tones, and a pleasing hint of sweet ferment.

Name: Estate Carbonic Maceration
Review: Delicately bittersweet and cocoa-toned, with flowers hinting at lushness.
Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing region, Big Island of Hawaii

Name: Ethiopia Dry-Processed Guji Mt. Kayon
Review: A regal and expressive natural-processed Ethiopia coffee with an inviting hint of clean, sweet ferment suggesting aged rum.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Ethiopia Banko Gotiti
Review: A juicy-sweet Ethiopia natural cup: lively and fruit-toned, with a hint of elegant, rum-like sweet ferment.
Coffee Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Colombia David Gomez 100% Caturra
Review: Engaging Colombia cup with impressively juicy, bright acidity and zesty, spice-toned aromatics.

Name: Guatemala Acatenango Gesha Lot #209
Review: A deep, graceful Guatemala Gesha cup, with notes of dried stone fruit grounded by rich chocolate tones.

Name: Panama Auromar Estate Geisha Peaberry
Review: A vibrant, exhilarating natural-processed peaberry Gesha saturated with rich floral, spice and fruit aromas and flavors throughout the profile.
Coffee Origin: Piedra Candela, Chiriqui Province, far western Panama

Name: Indonesia Emerald Mandheling
Review: Complex and dynamic in structure, balancing tart, sweet and bitter, with deeply layered and complex aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Gayo (also Aceh) growing region, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Panama Finca Hartmann Geisha Natural
Review: An exciting natural-processed Geisha that leads with juicy fruit notes and deeply sweet florals, all wrapped in frankincense and cocoa.

Name: Ethiopia Reko Estate Yirgacheffe
Review: Expresses the deep, spicy-sweet side of the Yirgacheffe profile, engaging in its balance of savory depth and perfumy sweetness.

Name: Costa Rica Sonora Estate Venecia Natural
Review: An engaging natural-processed Costa Rica cup, with top notes of peach and undercurrents of wood-framed florals throughout.

Name: Mini-Me Washed Kaffa Forest
Review: A dynamic trifecta of flowers, fruit and chocolate in both the shot and in cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Jade Espresso
Review: Deep, rich, gently tart, chocolaty as a straight shot; gloriously dessert-like in three parts milk.

Name: Estate Medium Roast
Review: A coffee both classic in its crisp clarity and subtly original in its high-toned fruit and floral aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing region, Big Island of Hawaii

Name: Ethiopia Holy Grail Natural Yirgacheffe
Review: In the straight shot, dark chocolate and tart fruit reign; in milk, spicy floral notes wrapped in chocolate carry the day.

Name: Ethiopia Agakiso
Review: A crisply sweet, inviting Ethiopia cup with pretty notes of black cherry and vanilla-like florals enveloped in cocoa-toned sandalwood.

Name: Kenya Karinga
Review: An intense yet accessible Kenya animated by a zesty but very sweet structure and an intriguing range of aromatics.

Name: Espresso Classico
Review: Deeply and sweetly pungent, plump-bodied and resonantly original in its aromatics.

Name: Thailand Doi Pangkhon Espresso
Review: A bright, vivid espresso: Tart citrus in front, enveloped by a softening chocolate.
Coffee Origin: Doi Pangkhon growing region, northern Thailand

Name: Ulos Batak Sumatra
Review: An intricately layered, superb Sumatra cup saturated with chocolate, spicy floral and sweet fruit notes, with gentle intimations of rich perique tobacco.

Name: Gaitania Colombia
Review: An inviting and accessible Colombia cup, sweet-toned with a hint of cardamom-like spice.

Name: Blue Label La Esmeralda Porton Pascua Gesha
Review: A symphonic Gesha cup: high-toned fruit and flowers are supported by spice and aromatic wood.

Name: Auromar Gesha Natural
Review: A crisp, deeply sweet natural-processed Gesha cup: chocolaty, fruit-toned and floral.
Coffee Origin: Piedra Candela, Chiriqui Province, far western Panama

Name: Haraz Special Red Yemen
Review: An attractively idiosyncratic cup from one of coffee’s ancient homelands: mildly fermenty, richly fruity-toned, with hints of earth and tobacco.

Name: David Mburu Kenya
Review: A big, juicy Kenya that invokes the tropics: resonant notes of aromatic orchid and coconut, along with hints of elegant musk and dried fig.

Name: “Naturals”
Review: A fruit-driven, but crisp natural-processed Kona cup that’s also certified organic.
Coffee Origin: Captain Cook, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii

Name: Finca Merced Guatemala
Review: A sweetly bright, cocoa-toned Guatemala cup with engaging stone fruit and aromatic wood complications.

Name: El Peñon Nicaragua
Review: Coffee Review’s highest scoring Nicaragua coffee of 2017: crystalline in structure, intensely aromatic, deeply and richly sweet.

Name: Kenya Chorongi Peaberry
Review: A classic Kenya cup: richly sweet-savory, with a complex array of fruit, floral, chocolate and aromatic wood notes at its intense and inviting heart.
Coffee Origin: Mukaro, Nyeri growing region, south-central Kenya

Name: Honduras Los Catadores Honey
Review: A solid single-origin Central America espresso, chocolate-toned throughout, with pretty floral and citrus zest grace notes.
Coffee Origin: Marcala growing region, La Paz Department, Honduras

Name: Static Kenya Kavutiri
Review: A delicate, spice-driven Kenya cup with engaging undercurrents of fruit, floral and chocolate.

Name: Honduras La Lesquinada Washed
Review: Makes a particularly appealing espresso in cappuccino-scaled milk: chocolaty, with intense fruit and floral complication.

Name: Kenya Gicherori
Review: A round, sweetly savory Kenya enlivened by the quiet intrigue of vanilla-like flowers and crisp chocolate.

Name: Static Colombia Decaf Midnight
Review: A solid, chocolate-toned decaf with inviting fruit and floral tones.

Name: Kenya Riakiberu AB
Review: A beautifully composed classic Kenya cup, with bright and deeply sweet fruit notes, big florals, solid chocolate and a hint of floral-toned spice.

Name: Diima #9 Ethiopia Natural
Review: This natural-processed Yirgacheffe’s hint of sweet, rum-like fruit ferment gives the cup a distinct holiday feel.

Name: Sweet Holiday Blend
Review: A brightly juicy, sweet blend with richly layered holiday nuance: chocolate, clove, date.

Name: DR Congo Virunga Organic
Review: An exciting coffee from a newly emerging eastern Congo growing region: savory-edged, richly sweet, invitingly pungent.
Coffee Origin: Kirumba, North Kivu Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: A lovely blend of four exceptional coffees that nets a crisp, very sweet, pleasingly herb-toned cup.

Name: Kenya Thaitu
Review: A spice-toned, floral- and fruit-driven Kenya coffee, grounded by rich chocolate notes with hints of sweet pipe tobacco.

Name: Yule Blend 2018
Review: A balanced, savory-leaning and richly sweet blend of two quality coffees from Kenya, netting a vibrantly high-toned, spice-driven cup.

Name: Los Congos Pacamara Honey
Review: An umami-driven Pacamara coffee, with a throughline of berry and sundried tomato notes: sweet and savory in harmonious balance.

Name: Coffea Diversa Costa Rica Sudan Rume
Review: A fine introduction to a rare variety of Arabica, Sudan Rume: crisp, bright, sweetly tart.

Name: Ethiopia Banko Gotiti Natural G1
Review: An inviting natural-processed coffee from Ethiopia: sweetly tart, fruit-forward.
Coffee Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Panama Auromar Geisha Natural
Review: A dynamic coffee with complex aromatics that invoke the tropics—and a seemingly infinite finish, richly sweet and flavor-saturated.
Coffee Origin: Piedra Candela, Chiriqui Province, far western Panama

Name: El Salvador Finca Kilimanjaro
Review: A graceful, generously fruit- and floral-toned El Salvador cup with an exceptionally balanced structure and juicy acidity.

Name: Panama Elida Green Tip Gesha Natural
Review: An elegant, richly sweet natural-processed Panama Gesha with berry and chocolate notes throughout.

Name: Gikanda Kenya
Review: Superb version of the classic sweet-savory, crisply juicy, fragrantly floral-edged Kenya cup.

Name: Panama Don Julian Pacamara
Review: Superb Pacamara profile, crisply dry and spicy yet deeply, lavishly juicy sweet.

Name: 100% Kona Bourbon Pointu Laurina
Review: Intense, bright but balanced cup with layered aromatic intrigue generated by a celebrated and rare tree variety.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii

Name: Kenya AB Muchoki
Review: The exciting Kenya tension between sweet and savory-tart is on display here, but a bit softer in expression perhaps, more tropical, than usual. A relaxed Kenya, authoritative yet delicate and approachable.

Name: Colombia Nariño Duende
Review: Low-toned and deeply rich, reminiscent of Ibarra Mexican chocolate with cinnamon, enveloped in fruit and nut tones.

Name: Geisha Panama Santamaria Natural
Review: Both elegantly balanced and subtly grand in detail; a quietly spectacular rendition of the Gesha profile.

Name: Decaf Colombia Select
Review: Those who value a gently zesty sweetness should enjoy this delicate decaf cup. Easy on the palate, easy on the nervous system.

Name: Ethiopia Awassa
Review: An engaging, confident Ethiopia cup with layered intrigue: flowers, fruit, aromatic wood.

Name: The Knight Dark Roast
Review: A solid K-cup blend with a caramel throughline: rich, sweet and round with hints of spicy flowers throughout.

Name: 100% Kona SL-28
Review: Coffee simply doesn’t get much better than this. Transcendently classic.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii

Name: Kenya Kirinyaga Mukangu AB
Review: A Kenya that covers all the bases: sweet-tart fruit, savory depth, spicy florals and cocoa.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Othaya Gatugi Red Cherry Project AA
Review: A darker roast develops a savory-toned chocolate to complement a zesty citrus in this pleasingly contradictory Kenya.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Yirgacheffe Adado
Review: A bright, lively, juicy washed Yirgacheffe coffee: classic in structure and style.

Name: Outbound Espresso
Review: An espresso blend that offers both high-toned florals and low-toned nut and chocolate notes, integrated by a consistent caramel throughline.

Name: Ace Espresso
Review: A floral-toned, richly sweet espresso blend: balanced, flavor-laden, driven by notes of narcissus-like flowers.

Name: Kenya Mutungati
Review: A vibrant fruit- and chocolate-toned Kenya coffee, with an exciting hint of lime zest throughout the profile.

Name: Guatemala El Retiro del Quisaya
Review: Delicate and graceful, yet authoritative in character; seductively sweet.
Coffee Origin: San Martin Jilotepeque, Chimaltenango Department, Guatemala

Name: Kenya Peaberry Kericho County
Review: An unorthodox but original and engaging variation on the Kenya cup, juxtaposing sweetness and a musky, herby-savory edge.

Name: Static El Salvador Finca Maria Luisa
Review: Those who value brisk, dry beverages should enjoy this coffee and its quiet, unorthodox aromatic intrigue.
Coffee Origin: Santa Rosa, La Unión Department, El Salvador

Name: Kamwangi Kenya
Review: Resonantly pungent Kenya, particularly attractive for its structure: sweet, tart and savory all at once, zesty yet seductive. Holds its character superbly as it cools.
Coffee Origin: Gichugu Division, Kirinyaga County, central Kenya

Name: Ethiopia Gelana Abaya
Review: Spicy-sweet, autumnal profile, complex and grown-up.

Name: Christmas Blend
Review: A lively, engaging spice-toned blend: crisp and richly sweet.

Name: Thanksgiving Blend
Review: An engaging, richly sweet blend that will appeal to those who enjoy, for example, the crisp caramel tones of the crust on a creme brulee dessert.

Name: Ethiopia Bishan Fugu
Review: A richly elegant cup that leads with deep fruit notes, as do many natural- processed coffees, though here the fruit is complicated by an engaging musk-like intrigue.
Coffee Origin: Hambela District, Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Sustainable Harvest Homacho Waeno Natural
Review: A natural-processed Ethiopia coffee of intriguing depth, with a wide range of aroma/flavor notes, savory pipe tobacco to high-toned, spicy florals, to crisply sweet citrus marmalade.
Coffee Origin: Aleta Wondo, Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Ethiopia Amaro Gayo Natural
Review: The overall impression of this natural-processed Yirgacheffe cup is equal parts dried fruit and chocolate, nicely elaborated by spice suggestions (cinnamon, clove, nutmeg).

Name: Ethiopia Shakiso Mormora
Review: A gently spice-toned, floral- driven wet-processed Ethiopia cup with pleasing notes of cocoa throughout.

Name: Ethiopia Suke Quto
Review: Lavender-like flowers and hints of zesty pink peppercorn animate this crisply sweet wet-processed Ethiopia cup.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Ethiopia Gedeb Halo Beriti
Review: A deeply and generously lush cup saved from sentimentality by a crisp, incense-like, slightly savory edge. Very wide range of aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia

Name: Ethiopia Kayon Mountain
Review: A lively and crisply sweet, fruit-forward natural-processed Ethiopia cup.
Coffee Origin: Odo Shakiso District, Guji Zone, southern Ethiopia

Name: Ethiopia Gelgelu Natural Organic
Review: A deeply sweet natural-processed Ethiopia cup, with stone fruit and brandy notes as parallel throughlines.

Name: Ethiopia Hambela Alaka
Review: A delicate, richly sweet wet-processed Ethiopia: spice, herb, fruit and flowers in intricate balance.
Coffee Origin: Hambela Wamena District, Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Organic Ethiopia Kirite
Review: An inviting wet-processed Ethiopia cup. Invokes a walk through a citrus orchard in spring, with a bonus of sweet herb and cocoa tones.
Coffee Origin: Hambela District, Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Ethiopia Sidama
Review: An elegantly expressive, fruit-forward but savory-leaning Ethiopia cup.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Thiriku AA Kenya
Review: Mysterious and extraordinary in the Kenya style: simultaneously sweet, savory, tart and entirely and grandly vibrant.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Tore
Review: An intense cup, zesty but juicy, alive with rose-like flowers, mint and lime.
Coffee Origin: Tore Village, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Direct Fair Trade Espresso
Review: A solid espresso blend equally pleasing as a straight shot and in milk.

Name: Decaf Ethiopia Sidamo
Review: This very light-roasted decaffeinated coffee may suggest a fine, complex Chinese black tea in some respects, though it ultimately enforces its coffee identity with its tart structure and light-footed authority. Oddly idiosyncratic in its aromatics, but quite free of the disturbing wood notes characteristic of many decaffeinated coffees.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: “Flowery” Espresso Blend
Review: An accessible, sweetly tart espresso blend, citrusy in the straight shot and chocolate-toned in milk.

Name: “Chocolate” Espresso Blend
Review: Chocolaty but rather austere and bittersweet blend.

Name: “Nutty” Espresso Blend
Review: Nut and chocolate dominate in this crisp, briskly dry espresso blend.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Washed G1
Review: A cup with a fine-tea-like appeal in its subtle complexity and spice-toned presentation.

Name: “Blue Mountain Flavor” Blend
Review: A balanced, high-toned cup with attractive chocolate notes complicated by hints of sweet herbs throughout.

Name: House Blend Espresso
Review: An espresso blend especially inviting in milk, where nut-toned chocolate and crisp fruit, with a hint of spice, converge.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Natural G1
Review: A crisply bittersweet cup that leads with spicy florals and sweet herb notes.

Name: “Fruity” Espresso Blend
Review: Rich, sweet, elegant and cocoa-laden, this espresso blend is nougat-like in the straight shot and fruit- and floral-toned in milk.

Name: “Sweety” Espresso Blend
Review: A radiant espresso blend that shines equally in the straight shot and in milk, alive with notes of rich dark chocolate and black cherry.

Name: Flora Blend Espresso
Review: A floral-driven straight shot, amplified with notes of stone fruit and chocolate in cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Static Kenya Kirimahiga
Review: An engaging, classic Kenya cup, with sweet and savory notes in balance, including an intriguing undertone suggesting the flavor of Russian rye bread.

Name: Washed Ethiopia Worka
Review: A deeply sweet wet-processed Ethiopia cup, spice-toned and redolent of dried stonefruit.

Name: Panama Finca San Sebastian
Review: A straight-ahead Panama cup: crisp, citrus- and chocolate-toned with inviting tropical fruit notes.

Name: El Aquila Pacamara Espresso
Review: Sweet, tart and savory tastes and parallel aroma/flavor notes are enveloped in a fat, plush mouthfeel. Fine example of a single-origin espresso, distinctively different yet complete and balanced, impressive both as a straight shot and in milk.

Name: Kenya AA Gicheroi
Review: A deeply intense, focused Kenya coffee with an especially appealing mouthfeel, velvety and lively.

Name: Guatemala Finca El Injerto Gesha
Review: A compelling Gesha coffee from Guatemala, at turns sweet, savory, tart and spice-toned, all in harmonious balance.

Name: Sumatra Afro-Gayo
Review: An accessible, sweet-toned cup, crisp and balanced with a throughline of cocoa and aromatic wood notes.
Coffee Origin: Gayo (also Aceh) growing region, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Panama Duncan Estate Wine-Processed
Review: An unusual variation on the dry or natural process applied to a fine Panama coffee, netting a cup rich with chocolate and fruit notes: elegant, high-toned, with pleasing notes of sweet ferment.
Coffee Origin: El Salto, Boquete growing region, Panama

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Nansebo Station Espresso
Review: A balanced, accessible single-origin espresso, cocoa- and floral-toned in milk.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Typica Baishengcun Farm
Review: Deeply rich, fruit-toned. Strawberry jam, roasted cacao nib, juniper wood, almond, tiger lily in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure; delicate, silky mouthfeel. The richly drying finish centers around crisp fruit notes (strawberry) framed by juniper-like aromatic wood notes.

Name: Kenya Gatomboya AA
Review: Hits all the classic Kenya notes: pungent with deep fruit and florals, supported by a simultaneously bright yet savory structure.

Name: Flight Seasonal Espresso
Review: A tour-de-force espresso composed of a fruit-driven, spice-toned blend of Colombia, Ethiopia and Kenya coffees: richly bittersweet, with deeply expressed fruit and florals.

Name: A.G.E. Duetto Espresso
Review: A gorgeous fruit- and floral-toned espresso, the pleasures of which are both intensified and deepened in milk, where a tropical theme (coconut, lychee) emerges.

Name: Ethiopia Kochere G1 Lot 096/183
Review: A crisply sweet wet-processed Ethiopia cup, delicate yet intriguing in its spice and flowers.

Name: Ethiopia Deri Kochere
Review: A richly sweet, spice-toned washed Ethiopia cup, with a throughline of intriguing bergamot and fennel-like notes.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Chelelektu
Review: An understated Yirgacheffe cup, quiet in aroma, with a balanced sweet-savory through-line carried by apricot and spicy aromatic wood notes.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Hill Farm
Review: A thrilling ride of a Kenya: balanced, deep, rich, and intriguingly spice-toned.

Name: Costa Rica Cumbres del Poas “Perla Negra”
Review: An engaging natural-processed Costa Rica driven by spicy floral notes and suggestions of dried stone fruit. Organically grown.
Coffee Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela growing region, Costa Rica

Name: Gold Mountain Coffee Growers Daniel’s Caturra Microlot
Review: Original in aromatics and deep in structure. Savory-leaning with rich sweetness and a spice throughline.

Name: Santa Maria Natural Yellow Catuai
Review: An impressive dried-in-the-fruit or “natural”-processed coffee, a tour-de-force of rich fruit, spicy floral, and sweet herb notes.

Name: Nicaragua Limoncillo Funky
Review: More elegant than the term “funky” implies; nonetheless will most appeal to those who enjoy coffees that are decidedly driven by the richness of deep fruit notes.

Name: Nicaragua Pacamara Honey Finca Cerro de Jesus
Review: A rich, engaging honey-processed Pacamara cup with a throughline of sweet herb notes.

Name: Tolliver’s Reserve Nicaragua Gold Mountain Fruit Candy Nanolot
Review: As the coffee’s name implies, the cup is characterized by notes suggesting tangy hard candy (watermelon, green apple), complicated by sweet-toned spices and aromatic wood.

Name: Los Congos Washed
Review: A crisp, balanced sweet-toned cup with the intrigue of pleasingly bitter floral and herb notes.

Name: Organic Shade-Grown Nicaragua
Review: A solid, complexly structured coffee from a roaster that has supported the coffee producers of Nicaragua for decades, through thick and thin. The Smithsonian Bird-Friendly certification is a rare and impeccable environmental credential.

Name: Nicaragua Un Regalo de Dios Bourbon
Review: A confident floral and sweetly spice-toned Nicaragua from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety: elegant, deeply rich, sweetly and roundly resonant.

Name: Jinotega Geisha
Review: An engaging ride of a Nicaragua Gesha: high-toned, balanced, discreetly confident, complete.

Name: Bernachon B888 Espresso
Review: A richly floral-toned, chocolaty espresso blend, especially attractive in milk.

Name: Mei-Chu Blend
Review: Travels seamlessly through sweet fruit, spicy floral and rich aromatic wood notes; surprising but always graceful.

Name: Gedeb Lot 83 Ethiopia Natural
Review: An elegant, sensuous experience of a dried-in-the-fruit or natural-processed Ethiopia coffee. Harmoniously sweet, tart and savory with a stunning range of aromatic intrigue.
Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia

Name: Halo Beriti Ethiopia
Review: An unusual washed Ethiopia cup, suggesting a very adult version of a chocolate and root beer float perhaps, but with deep floral and fruit complications.
Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia

Name: Mutitu Kenya
Review: A flavor-saturated Kenya cup characterized by sweet fruit and floral tones at the top, fine musk and chocolate underneath.

Name: Guaya’b Guatemala
Review: An inviting Guatemala, notable for its savory, tart-leaning sweetness, high-toned and layered.

Name: El Aquila Pacamara El Salvador
Review: Offers the depth and balance of a fine Pacamara, simultaneously sweet, savory and tart, with a quietly resonant set of aroma and flavor notes.

Name: Ethiopia Konga Sede
Review: A washed Ethiopia cup with a lot going on: high-toned fruit, crisply sweet citrus zest, and a confident ballast of herb-laced butterscotch.

Name: Colombia La Guamera
Review: A surprising Colombia cup, unconventional in regard to processing method (dried-in-the-fruit full natural), which contributes to a fruit-forward, yet cohesively balanced, profile.

Name: Static Amaro Gayo Natural Ethiopia
Review: A thrill of a natural-processed Ethiopia: fruit, florals and savory notes in intricate, lively harmony.

Name: Static Cali Classic Espresso
Review: A deeply sweet, richly pungent espresso blend, compelling in its confident spice tones (caraway, licorice root) and balanced sweet-savory-tart structure.

Name: Static Dark Star Mexico Espresso
Review: An impressively balanced, energetic chocolate- and stonefruit-toned espresso from Mexico, an origin seldom show-cased in single-origin espressos.

Name: Static Hacienda Sonora Costa Rica
Review: A simultaneously savory-leaning yet floral- and sweet-toned honey-processed coffee.

Name: Static Don Eli La Pastora Tarrazu Costa Rica
Review: A honey-processed Costa Rica cup, enticing for its high-toned, vivacious herb notes enveloped in suggestions of rich florals and sweet nuts.

Name: Static Rio Negro Huila Supremo
Review: A big-bodied Colombia that leads unapologetically and impressively with sweet-toned spice notes.

Name: Static Ethiopia Koke
Review: An inviting honey-processed Ethiopia, with cocoa, fruit and floral notes both rounded and turned gently crisp by a tactful medium-dark roast.

Name: Static Adado Shara
Review: An interesting choice for those who prefer to find the sweetness in their cup expressed in floral and aromatic wood notes rather than in the more typical fruit.

Name: Static San Augustin Guatemala
Review: A roast at the edge between medium and medium-dark promotes pleasant smoke notes in this Guatemala, while still allowing spice, fruit and floral notes to exert their presence and authority.

Name: Static Peaberry Cerrado Brazil
Review: An aromatic-wood-framed Brazil peaberry with pretty floral undertones.
Coffee Origin: Cerrado growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Static Ravens Dark Roast Mexico
Review: The bittersweet structure, dried fruit notes and vanilla-toned flowers pleasantly nudge this coffee toward a darker roast profile, even though this is a medium-roasted bean.

Name: Shine Day El Salvador
Review: A bright, even lyrical, floral- and fruit-driven cup.

Name: Kenya Kirinyaga Baragwi Guama AB
Review: A decisively Kenya cup with classic notes of red currant throughout, grounded and balanced by tropical nut tones and crisply sweet, concentrated florals.

Name: Guatemala Finca El General Espresso
Review: A high-toned, richly sweet-tart espresso, equally attractive as a straight shot or in milk.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Adado
Review: An appealingly meandering, spice-toned floral cup, centered on the ripe, faintly fermenty blueberry notes often pleasingly characteristic of dried-in-the-fruit or “natural”-processed coffees like this one.

Name: Kenya AA Nyeri
Review: A light-footed and crisply elegant Kenya; if the big, emphatic Kenyas are Cabernets, this one is a Pinot Noir.

Name: Uganda Fair Trade Bukonzo
Review: Although Uganda has struggled over the years to produce top Arabica coffees worthy of its excellent terroirs and hard-working growers, producers have clearly succeeded here with this very impressive, quite distinctive offering in the deep, resonant style of the best Central Africa coffees.

Name: Ethiopia Limmu Organic Kebena Kossa
Review: A crisp, high-toned dried-in-the-fruit or “natural”-processed Ethiopia driven by berry notes with a hint of sweet fruit ferment and grounded by intimations of cocoa and sweet herbs.
Coffee Origin: LImmu Woreda, Oromia Zone, southern Ethiopia

Name: Honduras Finca Jerusalen
Review: Unusual Central America profile, tart but starchy, candyish yet savory. Those who value the sweet/savory coffees of Central Africa origins like Rwanda or Burundi may particularly enjoy this attractive but atypical Honduras.
Coffee Origin: Marcala growing region, La Paz Department, Honduras

Name: Ethiopia Shakisso
Review: A light-footed, vivacious wet-processed Ethiopia cup. Might make a refreshing cold or iced coffee.

Name: Colombia Finca Campoalegre
Review: A nuanced, complex Colombia cup that leads with lush floral notes and stone fruit grounded by suggestions of rich cocoa.

Name: Kenya Boma AA
Review: An elegant and complete Kenya; pungent, delicate yet deep. Think fine red table wines.
Coffee Origin: Baringo and Nakura Counties, central Kenya

Name: Ethiopia Guji Zone Natural
Review: Offers a nuanced experience of a dried-in-the-fruit or “natural”-processed Ethiopia, with both high- and low-toned florals (citrus blossom and fine musk) as the thesis of the cup.

Name: Kenya Boma Peaberry
Review: Classic Kenya cup: honey, citrus and spice.
Coffee Origin: Baringo and Nakura Counties, central Kenya

Name: Gesha Village Auction Lot 26 Gori Gesha Natural
Review: Lovely dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” profile, lush and opulent yet animated and gently bright.

Name: Gesha Village Lot 76 Nasha Block
Review: A light roast develops the delicacy and gentle vivacity of this cleanly understated yet spectacularly aromatic dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” Gesha profile.

Name: Gesha Village Natural Oma Block Lot 72
Review: Both zesty and richly floral, a dried-in-the-fruit Gesha cup offering an extraordinary range of striking but harmonious aroma and flavor notes.

Name: Gesha Village 1931, Lot 86
Review: A high-toned flowers-and-cocoa version of the Gesha profile, classic, intense and exhilarating.

Name: Esmeralda Special Auction Washed Geisha
Review: Crisp yet lush, deep, intricate, a classic Gesha from Hacienda Esmeralda, the ground zero of the Gesha variety’s take-off to fame.

Name: Panama Geisha
Review: Intensely sweet, intensely roasty, intensely Gesha. And given it’s Gesha, an impressive value.

Name: Guatemala Acatenango Gesha
Review: The Gesha character exerts a quiet but decisive influence in this classic, sweetly bright and balanced Guatemala.

Name: Gesha Village Ethiopia Lot #18 Illubabor Washed
Review: A crisp, resonant wet-processed version of the Gesha profile, simultaneously sweet and tartly drying, with an enriching musky, savory edge.

Name: Guatemala El Injerto Legendary Gesha
Review: Hints of Gesha complexity contribute resonant intrigue to this classic, gently pungent Guatemala.

Name: Carmen Geisha El Palomar Best of Panama #4 Carlos Aguilera
Review: Extraordinary shifting and intricate flavor and aroma supported by a flawless structure, classic in its sweet-tart balance.

Name: Kilenso Ethiopia Natural
Review: A lush, resonant dried-in-the-fruit coffee with a brisk edge: a fruit-bomb for grown-ups.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Brazil Paulo Ribeiro Rocha
Review: An accessible, deeply sweet, caramel-toned Brazil cup. Those who avoid aggressive acidity but enjoy a lighter-roasted, very gently bright cup should particularly value this selection.
Coffee Origin: Mantiqeiras de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Colombia Daniel Ortega
Review: A rich, complex, rather atypical Colombia coffee that deepens as you linger with the cup: bright but resonant, deeply spice-toned.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Washed Adado Gr 1
Review: A high-toned, elegantly crisp, washed Yirgacheffe cup with a cocoa throughline.

Name: Bella Carmona Guatemala
Review: A very distinctive and original Guatemala, fusing sweet/savory depth with delicate, lively nut and floral aromatics.

Name: Costa Rica La Cereza Roja Semi-Washed
Review: A discreetly fruit-toned, honey-processed coffee with aromatic wood notes as ballast.

Name: Karuthi Espresso
Review: A deeply engaging, sweetly savory Kenya espresso, striking, original yet complete, enticing both as straight shot and in milk.

Name: Chelelektu Espresso
Review: A compelling espresso as both straight shot and in cappuccino-scaled milk: delicate and deeply rich, with notes of tropical fruit, jasmine and crisp lemon zest.

Name: Chelelektu Ethiopia
Review: A sweet-toned, zesty washed Yirgacheffe coffee that leads with rich floral notes grounded by suggestions of grapefruit zest.

Name: Karuthi Kenya
Review: A deeply rich, layered Kenya cup with savory sweetness characteristic of this celebrated origin’s most classic coffees.

Name: Finca El Obraje Colombia Gesha
Review: The slightly darker roast is felt rather than tasted in this extraordinarily deeply stated, complete version of the great Gesha profile. Those who may enjoy the aromatic extravagance of the Gesha profile but put off by Gesha’s often brightly assertive acidity should particularly value this rounder, yet still exhilaratingly vibrant version.

Name: Kenya AA Top Nyeri Tekangu Tegu Microlot
Review: A distinct roasty edge complicates this superb Kenya, with its characteristic and engaging tart berry, grapefruit citrus and crisp floral notes.

Name: Peru Cajamarca Organic
Review: Quiet, elegant Peru, with chocolate and ripe fruit notes rounded and deepened by a very tactful, backgrounded medium-dark roast.

Name: Ethiopia Organic Dark
Review: A no-apologies dark roast that retains resonant complexity and vibrant balance throughout the profile.

Name: Chimney Rock Blend
Review: Crisply sweet roast-toned blend with a pleasing aromatic range: nut and chocolate with delicate stone fruit and floral complication.

Name: Sumatra Tanah Karo
Review: A rich, idiosyncratic version of an already idiosyncratic coffee type, a darker roasted wet-hulled Sumatra. We didn’t register much of the famous Sumatra earth or pipe tobacco, but we did get a big, spicy yet fudgy chocolate and a complex pungent sweetness.

Name: Duomo Espresso Northern Italian Style
Review: A quiet, accessible darker-roasted coffee, sweet and caramelly with a brisk, zesty edge.

Name: Mocha Java Blend Fair Trade Organic
Review: A twisty version of the ancient Mocha-Java blend, probably quite authentic with its suggestions of wood, spicy nut and chocolate.
